elements.title: Pyramid of Khentkaus I (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that an inscription uncovered at the Pyramid of Khentkaus I (pictured), identifies Khentkaus I as the mother of two kings, or perhaps the mother of one and a king herself?

elements.title: Gladys Boyd (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that Canadian paediatrician Gladys Boyd was one of the first physicians to treat diabetic children with insulin?

elements.title: Brandenburg (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that Jerome Robbins's final ballet, Brandenburg, set to excerpts from Bach's Brandenburg Concertos, is likened to a kaleidoscope?

elements.title: Athanasius Safar (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that Athanasius Safar, a Syriac Catholic bishop from the Ottoman Empire, left Europe for Mexico in 1689?

elements.title: Romanian United Socialist Party (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that following the ban of its labour unions in 1934, the Romanian United Socialist Party would rely on its youth and women's wings for political action?

elements.title: Clements twins (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that the Clements twins have an estimated revenue of almost US$6000 per Instagram post?

elements.title: Heart Gear (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that the Japanese manga series Heart Gear sells three times better in France than in Japan?

elements.title: Bangalore (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that the name of the Indian city Bangalore could be derived from a Kannada word meaning 'town of boiled beans'?
